title: Neue Rechte
text:
Neue Rechte ("New Right") is the designation for a <a href="right-wing%20politics">right-wing</a> political movement in <a href="Germany">Germany</a>. It was founded as an opposition to the <a href="New%20Left">New Left</a> generation of the 1960s. Its intellectually oriented proponents distance themselves from Old Right <a href="Nazism">Nazi</a> traditions and emphasize similarities between the <a href="far-right%20politics%20in%20Germany">far-right</a> and the <a href="conservatism%20in%20Germany">conservative</a> spectrum.
A common denominator of the Neue Rechte is a skeptical or negative stance towards the basic tenets of the <a href="German%20constitution">German constitution</a>, often in the sense of an <a href="ethnic%20nationalism">ethnic</a> ("<a href="V%C3%B6lkisch%20movement">völkisch</a>") nationalism.
History.
When in 1964 the far-right <a href="National%20Democratic%20Party%20of%20Germany">National Democratic Party of Germany</a> (NPD) was founded, its younger members began to call themselves "Junge Rechte", in order to differ from Nazi models and to counter the <a href="German%20student%20movement">German student movement</a>. Contrary to their hopes, the NPD failed to enter the <a href="Bundestag">Bundestag</a> parliament in the <a href="West%20German%20federal%20election%2C%201969">1969 federal elections</a>, whereafter they initiated a far-right renewal movement. In 1972, <a href="Henning%20Eichberg">Henning Eichberg</a> drafted the policy declaration of the "Aktion Neue Rechte" offshoot, conveying ideas of an 'anti-imperialistic liberation nationalism', which included the expulsion of the <a href="Allied-occupied%20Germany">Allied</a> 'occupying forces' to pave the way for German unification and national rebirth.
From 1974, the movement disintegrated into numerous splinter groups, some defending the traditional ideas of a German "<a href="Volksgemeinschaft">Volksgemeinschaft</a>", some affiliating to the rising <a href="Environmental%20movement">ecology movement</a>. Eichberg and his followers continued to fight an 'over-foreignization' ("<a href="%C3%9Cberfremdung">Überfremdung</a>") by the superpowers and advocated a <a href="Third%20Position">Third Position</a> in opposition to both capitalism and communism. They made attempts to build up ties to left-wing sectarian and ecological groups, as well as to the German <a href="peace%20movement">peace movement</a>.
About 1980, a new tendency arose to approach the ideas of the French <a href="Nouvelle%20Droite">Nouvelle Droite</a> and its founder <a href="Alain%20de%20Benoist">Alain de Benoist</a>. The adherents stressed the perspective of a pan-European 'cultural struggle'; their concepts were embodied by the foundation of the <a href="Thule-Seminar">Thule-Seminar</a> as the German branch of the French <a href="Groupement%20de%20recherche%20et%20d%27%C3%A9tudes%20pour%20la%20civilisation%20europ%C3%A9enne">Groupement de recherche et d'études pour la civilisation européenne</a> (GRECE). In the late 1980s, proponents of a national revolutionary movement attempted to infiltrate <a href="Right-wing%20populism">right-wing populist</a> parties like <a href="The%20Republicans%20%28Germany%29">The Republicans</a>, while other associated with the <a href="National%20liberalism">national liberal</a> spectrum.
The movement gained a new momentum in the course of <a href="German%20reunification">German reunification</a>. The rise of right-wing parties as The Republicans led by <a href="Franz%20Sch%C3%B6nhuber">Franz Schönhuber</a>, the <a href="Pro%20Germany%20Citizens%27%20Movement">Pro Movement</a>, and the <a href="Alternative%20for%20Germany">Alternative for Germany</a> (AfD) is a matter of ongoing debate among German political scientists. They draw parallels to the success of European parties such as the Italian <a href="Alleanza%20Nazionale">Alleanza Nazionale</a> and the <a href="Lega%20Nord">Lega Nord</a>, the <a href="Freedom%20Party%20of%20Austria">Freedom Party of Austria</a> (FPÖ), the French <a href="Front%20National">Front National</a>, the <a href="Swiss%20People%27s%20Party">Swiss People's Party</a> (SVP) or the Belgian <a href="Vlaams%20Belang">Vlaams Belang</a> as well as to the US <a href="Tea%20Party%20movement">Tea Party movement</a>. The programmatic statements of 'New Right' parties span from neoliberal to far-right elements and thereby have become compatible to conservative and liberal circles.
Ideology.
Historically, the "Neue Rechte" is linked to the positions of right-wing Ideologues in the <a href="Weimar%20Republic">Weimar Republic</a>, later summarized under the heading '<a href="Conservative%20Revolution">Conservative Revolution</a>' by writers like <a href="Armin%20Mohler">Armin Mohler</a>. These forces included such people as <a href="Arthur%20Moeller%20van%20den%20Bruck">Arthur Moeller van den Bruck</a> ("<a href="Das%20Dritte%20Reich">Das Dritte Reich</a>"), <a href="Carl%20Schmitt">Carl Schmitt</a>, <a href="Edgar%20Julius%20Jung">Edgar Julius Jung</a>, <a href="Ernst%20J%C3%BCnger">Ernst Jünger</a>, <a href="Oswald%20Spengler">Oswald Spengler</a> ("<a href="The%20Decline%20of%20the%20West">The Decline of the West</a>") and <a href="Ernst%20von%20Salomon">Ernst von Salomon</a>. During the <a href="interwar%20period">interwar period</a>, they openly rejected <a href="Marxism">Marxism</a> as well as liberalism and the <a href="parliamentary%20system">parliamentary system</a> in favour of an <a href="Authoritarianism">authoritarian</a> regime and a German "<a href="Sonderweg">Sonderweg</a>". Their views towards rising Nazism remained ambivalent, nevertheless they contributed to the fierce political infighting that preceded the <a href="Nazi%20seizure%20of%20power">Nazi seizure of power</a> in 1933.
Several members of the "Neue Rechte" also refer to theorists like <a href="Georges%20Sorel">Georges Sorel</a>, <a href="Vilfredo%20Pareto">Vilfredo Pareto</a>, <a href="Robert%20Michels">Robert Michels</a>, <a href="Julius%20Evola">Julius Evola</a>, and <a href="Jos%C3%A9%20Antonio%20Primo%20de%20Rivera">José Antonio Primo de Rivera</a> seen as <a href="Fascism">fascist</a> pioneers. Some even base themselves on Marxist philosophers like <a href="Antonio%20Gramsci">Antonio Gramsci</a> and his ideas of <a href="cultural%20hegemony">cultural hegemony</a>.
Textually, the "Neue Rechte" challenges the principles of the <a href="Age%20of%20Enlightenment">Enlightenment</a>, such as <a href="pluralism%20%28political%20theory%29">pluralism</a> and <a href="social%20equality">social equality</a> underlying the doctrine of <a href="human%20rights">human rights</a>. Racist elements are superseded by the concept of <a href="ethnopluralism">ethnopluralism</a>, combining both <a href="Neoconservatism">neoconservative</a> and far-right approaches. Ideologists disparage the ideals of the <a href="Protests%20of%201968">1968 protests</a> and <a href="feminism">feminism</a>, they refuse to accept a <a href="Multiculturalism">multicultural</a> society and seek for a strengthened 'national identity'. Therefore, they tend to <a href="historical%20revisionism">historical revisionism</a> and to battle against what they call a German 'cult of guilt' with regard to <a href="The%20Holocaust">The Holocaust</a>. According to <a href="Roger%20Griffin">Roger Griffin</a>, the "Neue Rechte" share the deep <a href="cultural%20pessimism">cultural pessimism</a> of their precursors in the interwar period. Referring to a "völkisch" nationalism, the movement seeks refuge not in the restoration of traditional values, but in a 'national rebirth' according to <a href="Palingenetic%20ultranationalism">palingenetic</a> concepts.
They parallel the French "Nouvelle Droite" as a political movement, somewhat similar in their general political stance including the <a href="Anti-Americanism">Anti-American</a> sentiment advocated by Alain de Benoist. However, the "Nouvelle Droite"'s <a href="Neo-Paganism">neo-pagan</a> leanings are the opposite to the Christian foundation of many "Neue Rechte" members, though the movement also comprises <a href="occult">occult</a> groups.
So far, the "Neue Rechte" movement has not achieved an integrated opposite position to Western liberalism: while a main neoconservative tendency strongly refers to pre-war traditions and even affect <a href="centre-right%20politics">centre-right</a> parties, a second wing openly uses terms like "revolution" or "socialism" in political disputes, based on the model of <a href="Ernst%20Niekisch">Ernst Niekisch</a> and <a href="Strasserism">Strasserist</a> concepts. They have made attempts to build up a "Querfront" strategy with originally 'left' anti-imperialist and <a href="Anti-capitalism">anti-capitalist</a> circles.
Networks.
Well-known scholars and influential figures of the "Neue Rechte" beside Henning Eichberg and Armin Mohler include <a href="Gerd-Klaus%20Kaltenbrunner">Gerd-Klaus Kaltenbrunner</a>, Hans-Dietrich Sander, <a href="Robert%20Hepp">Robert Hepp</a>, <a href="Caspar%20von%20Schrenck-Notzing">Caspar von Schrenck-Notzing</a>, <a href="Karlheinz%20Weissmann">Karlheinz Weissmann</a> and <a href="G%C3%B6tz%20Kubitschek">Götz Kubitschek</a>.
The medium commonly associated with the "Neue Rechte" is the weekly newspaper "<a href="Junge%20Freiheit">Junge Freiheit</a>" founded in 1986. However, its chief editor Dieter Stein, a former member of The Republicans, denounces the term and instead advocates a more traditionally Christian, yet decidedly nationalist and democratic conservatism. Yet the term is frequently used as a self-description by the bi-monthly magazine "Sezession", which is closely linked to "Junge Freiheit". Other periodicals affiliated with the "Neue Rechte" are "<a href="Nation%20Europa">Nation und Europa</a>" (discontinued in 2009) and its "<a href="Zuerst%21">Zuerst!</a>" successor. The <a href="Studienzentrum%20Weikersheim">Studienzentrum Weikersheim</a> founded by the <a href="Christian%20Democratic%20Union%20of%20Germany">CDU</a> politician <a href="Hans%20Filbinger">Hans Filbinger</a> considers itself a Christian-conservative <a href="think%20tank">think tank</a>.
The <a href="Bibliothek%20des%20Konservatismus">Bibliothek des Konservatismus</a> (BdK) is another connecting element in the network of the far-right in central Europe. Opened in 2012 and located in Fasanenstraße in <a href="Berlin-Charlottenburg">Berlin-Charlottenburg</a> the main focus of the library is conservative and far-right literature. It is the first library with this content in Germany and was founded by <a href="Caspar%20von%20Schrenck-Notzing">Caspar von Schrenck-Notzing</a> and his foundation "Förderstiftung konservative Bildung und Forschung (FKBF)". FKBF is running the library. There are 27.000 medias (2014) in the library.
